name: Overlord™: Raising Hell
description: How evil can you get? Discover how corruptible you are in Overlord, the twisted fantasy action adventure where you can be evil (or really evil). In the game's seriously warped fantasy world, players will become the Overlord and get first-hand experience of how absolute power corrupts absolutely.

If you play a lot of minion master classes in MMO's you'll probably enjoy this game. You take control of a bunch of little imps and have them do whatever you want. You are also a warrior based class so you can fight things with your weapons but your little minions can also aid in the fight. They will also pickup small items in game and use them as weapons/armor if they are equippable. You start off with only the basic type of imp but later on you can get ones that can start using magic and some that can even swim around in water.
It's like a much more hands-on Dungeon Keeper, with fewer minions and more Rhianna Pratchett. Which is awesome.

In an interesting fusion of games like Pikmin and Fable, Overlord proves to be an enjoyable, albeit sinister experience from your initial awakening, all the way to your fated seat upon the throne of evil. Each step of the game brings you through lush, detailed landscapes, offers rich musical scores and introduces clever, original writing not present in a lot of games of its kind. With a well integrated moral choice system, you're not forced to be a 'bad good guy' as with most games. In fact, most choices are between evil and incredibly sadistic. Different abilities, storyline changes and even appearance alteration will supply some replayability. With its unique fusion of tactical, RPG and adventure elements, Overlord is sure to offer something for everyone. The expansion 'Raising Hell' adds even more to that experience with new bosses, areas to explore and items to obtain that ultimately help you unleash mayhem across the land as you truly live up to your title of 'Overlord'.

Note: this is a review for both the original game as well as the expansion, as steam seems to think they are one and the same.  Be Evil! That's the supposed attraction of Overlord, an interesting hybrid of tactical strategy, action RPG and adventure game, all wrapped in a purely satirical shell. However, how evil you actually get to be is rather low, being either murderous evil or the evil version of “nice by accident”. In either case being evil isn't really the attraction of the game, as much as it is about the parodic fun the game pokes at all things fantasy.   Which is good, because the battle system is unwieldy, the stages are sometimes a bit too long, and in the middle of the game the expectation of lifeforce to imbue into your weapons and armor vs the amount you actually have results in a near grinding halt of the gameplay as you grind away in your dungeon on beetles and their ilk. Clearly the game has some problems, not the least being the somewhat obtuse Hell stages of the Raising Hell DLC.  But it's all ok! Though those problems can be felt, they are helped along by a silly, interesting, goofy tale that really ends up being about revenge, sin, and what it really means to be evil . . . as well as by some fairly pretty graphics, even seven years past the game's release.  For anyone that enjoys a silly tale of fantasy parody and ordering goblin/gremlin-like minions to kill things, this is a game best picked up. Though if you can find this game, it's DLC and the second game on sale in the Overlord Complete Pack, I'd suggest that even more. ;)

Years ago when I was younger I played the original Overlord game and it's expansion Raising Hell. It was fun, but at the time I found Raising Hell lacking after coming off the colorful and vibrant Overlord main game. Nostalgia brought me back and time has aged this game finely.  Triumph has created a unique blend of army commanding with a standard action feel. By now it should be easy to see what the game is like, so as a PC port how does it hold up? Okay. There are a few awkward keybindings, but not atrocious. It runs smoothly, no chopping, scales up to High res monitors. Completely recommend this game.
